article.title: From Cellular Mechanotransduction to Biologically Inspired Engineering
article.abstract: This article reviews more than thirty years of research from my laboratory, beginning with studies designed to test the theory that cells use tensegrity architecture to stabilize their shape and sense mechanical signals.

sections.introduction: This article is based on the 2009 Pritzker Distinguished Award Lecture I presented to the Biomedical Engineering Society in the opening symposium of their annual meeting that was convened at Pittsburgh, PA in October 2009.

article.insights_summary: The article discusses the concept of cellular mechanotransduction and its role in cell function and tissue development. It highlights the importance of physical forces in shaping cell behavior and the potential for biologically inspired engineering approaches to develop new technologies.
article.acknowledgments: The research described in this lecture was supported by grants from NIH, NASA, NSF, DARPA, DoD, CIMIT, ARO, and Wyss Institute, and the author is a recipient of a DoD Breast Cancer Innovator Award.
